awd_titl_txt: Exploration of Pressure- and Field-Tuned Phenomena and Phases in Mn- and V-based Spinels
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract
"Magnetically responsive" materials have magnetic and conducting properties that can be sensitively tuned with pressure and magnetic field, and exhibit a range of scientifically interesting and technologically useful properties, including coexisting magnetic and electric orders, magnetic-field-induced shape and conductivity changes, and strain controlled magnetism.   Understanding the physical mechanisms responsible for these exotic properties is not only important scientifically, but is an essential prerequisite to optimizing these materials for use in technological applications. This project combines the use of high pressures, high magnetic fields, and visible laser light to identify and control the underlying mechanisms responsible for magnetically responsive behavior in a select group of magnetically responsive materials.  Among the goals of this project are to identify the key physical mechanisms that give rise to magnetically responsive behavior, to control these mechanisms in order to create novel properties of scientific and technological interest, and to investigate as-yet-unexplored phase regions to uncover new, and potentially useful, physical properties.  The diverse techniques employed in this research - including high-pressure techniques using diamond anvil cell technology, high-magnetic-field and low-temperature methods, optical and laser techniques, and materials growth methods - provide the graduate and undergraduate student researchers outstanding training for a diverse range of careers in academia, industry, or national laboratories.  This project is also dedicated to imparting scientific literacy and enthusiasm for science in both the general public and K-12 students, through public lectures on science, middle-school scientific demonstrations, and lab tours that highlight the excitement of the materials studied and the scientific techniques used in this project.

Technical abstract
Magnetically frustrated materials, such as the magnetic spinels (chemical formula AB2X4), exhibit a range of diverse ground state phases and phenomena that can be sensitively tuned with pressure and magnetic field, including spin-spiral, charge-ordered, multiferroic, and spin/orbital-liquid phases.  The exceptional tunability of the spinels and other magnetically responsive materials make them excellent scientific laboratories in which myriad phases and phenomena can be sensitively controlled and studied.  Yet, there is limited microscopic understanding of the microscopic magnetostructural effects that lead to the important pressure- and field-tuned behaviors these materials exhibit, due largely to the absence of spectroscopic information as to how the spin- and lattice-dynamics of magnetically frustrated materials change as functions of magnetic field and pressure.  The purpose of this research is to fill this important gap in our understanding by using inelastic light scattering techniques to study the spin- and lattice-excitations of select magnetically frustrated materials while field- and pressure-tuning through their diverse phases.  The goals of this research are to elucidate the microscopic magnetostructural changes responsible for novel magnetoresponsive behavior in magnetically frustrated materials, to use applied field and pressure to control different magnetoresponsive behaviors, and to explore previously unaccessed phase regimes and phenomena in magnetically responsive materials under high pressures and magnetic fields. In addition to providing diverse technical training to several graduate and undergraduate students, this research will impact the broader community through laboratory tours aimed at exposing K-12 students and teachers to the excitement of materials research, and through optics-related demonstrations to middle schools students.

por.por_cntn:
This project combines the use of high pressures, high magnetic fields, and inelastic light scattering to identify and control the underlying mechanisms responsible for magnetically responsive behavior in a select group of highly functional magnetic materials. The projects described have important technological implications, because they reveal the underlying mechanisms that allow the magnetic states of magnetic materials to be sensitively controlled for potential device applications.

The intellectual merits of this project includes: (i) we demonstrated that the low-field (H  less than 1.5 T) spin dynamics of Sr2IrO4 exhibit important effects associated with interlayer coupling and in-plane anisotropy that are not accounted for in standard theoretical descriptions of the spin dynamics of Sr2IrO4 (see figure to right).  (ii) We discovered an anomalously large intensity associated with a magnon having chiral symmetry in multiferroic CoCr2O4 (see figure), which reveals strong magneto-optical effects associated with this mode.  We further showed that the strong magnetodielectric behavior in this material arises from the field-dependent suppression of magnetic fluctuations that are strongly coupled to phonons.  The application of pressure was shown to suppress the magnetodielectric response by increasing magnetic anisotropy and exchange (see figure), suggesting the magnetodielectric behavior in CoCr2O4 can be sensitively controlled using pressure or epitaxial strain. (iii) We showed that the magnetostructural configurations of magnetodielectric Mn3O4 can be sensitively tuned with magnetic field (see figure) due to the presence of domain walls. We also demonstrated that applied pressure can be used as a sensitive tuning parameter to control the magnetic phases of multiferroic materials Mn3O4 and MnV2O4, as evidenced by dramatic changes in the magnon and phonon spectra of Mn3O4 (see figure). These studies show for the first time that multifunctional behavior in magnetic spinels is likely associated with field- and strain-induced domain-wall motion, offering insight into how complex materials can be engineered to have enhanced susceptibilities to magnetic field and strain. (iv)  Magnetic force microscopy measurements of Mn3O4 were also conducted to directly image the nanometer-scale magnetic domains and confirm that the field- and pressure-sensitivities of phases in Mn3O4 are associated with field- and strain-tuning of magnetic domain walls. 

Among the broader impacts of this project: (i) The participation of women in physics was broadened through support of two female PhD students. (ii) Single-crystal samples of CoCr2O4 and Mn3O4 were produced and are being distributed to others in the scientific community. (iii) The PI organized a Physics Careers seminar, which brought in 44 PhD alumni over the past 4 years to discuss different career paths for physics PhD students (see figure). (iv) The PI has worked toward broadening participation in physics graduate school during the funding cycle of this grant through membership in the NSF-sponsored IGEN network (see figure), which aims to improve admission practices for underrepresented (URM) physics students, and by serving as co-PI of the Illinois Sloan Center for Exemplary Mentoring, which is improving mentoring practices for URM PhD students in STEM fields. (v) The PI encouraged undergraduate students to pursue graduate school in physics and other STEM fields by giving talks on "Graduate School: Why Go and How To Get In," and by participating in nationally broadcast APS webinars on "Physics Graduate School: Tips for Applying" (Nov. 2016) and "Physics Graduate School: Your Questions Answered" (Nov. 2017), both now on YouTube. (vi) The PI worked towards improving the scientific communication skills of PhD students by teaching a scientific communications course each spring during the funding period, which provided roughly 64 PhD students from 7 STEM departments training in scientific communication, proposal writing, etc.
